text:
Read the following extract and answer the questions that follow.

I wrote some lines once on a time
In wondrous merry mood,
And thought, as usual, men would say
They were exceeding good.

They were so queer, so very queer,
I laughed as I would die;
Albeit, in the general way,
A sober man am I.

I called my servant, and he came;
How kind it was of him
To mind a slender man like me,
He of the mighty limb.

A1. Simple Factual (2 marks)
Complete the following sentences:
(i) The poet wrote some lines when he was in a _______ mood.
(ii) The poet describes himself as a _______ man.

A2. Complex Factual (2 marks)
What was the poet's initial thought about the lines he had written? Why did he laugh?

A3. Poetic Device (1 mark)
Identify and explain the rhyme scheme of the first stanza.
answer:
A1.
(i) The poet wrote some lines when he was in a wondrous merry mood.
(ii) The poet describes himself as a sober man.

A2. The poet's initial thought was that people would, as usual, say that his lines were exceedingly good. He laughed because he himself found the lines to be extremely strange and funny ('so queer, so very queer').

A3. The rhyme scheme of the first stanza is ABCB. 'time' (A), 'mood' (B), 'say' (C), 'good' (B).

text:
Write the appreciation of the poem 'The Height of the Ridiculous'. You can use the following points:
  • About the poem/poet and the title
  • The theme
  • Poetic style, language, poetic devices
  • Special features/message
  • Your opinion about the poem
answer:
Appreciation of the Poem

About the Poem/Poet: 'The Height of the Ridiculous' is a humorous poem written by the American poet Oliver Wendell Holmes. The title itself suggests that the poem is about something that is extremely absurd or funny.

Theme: The central theme of the poem is the overwhelming power of humour. The poet describes a situation where a poem he writes is so funny that it causes an extreme, almost fatal, physical reaction in the person who reads it, highlighting the physical effects of uncontrollable laughter.

Poetic Style and Devices: The poem is a narrative ballad, written in short, four-line stanzas (quatrains) with a simple ABCB rhyme scheme. The language is light and humorous. The main poetic device is Hyperbole (exaggeration), which is used throughout the poem to describe the servant's reaction (e.g., 'A dreadful grin,/ That spread from ear to ear'). The poet also uses Alliteration (e.g., 'merry mood').

Special Features/Message: The poem's special feature is its comical and exaggerated storytelling, which creates a very light-hearted and entertaining tone. The underlying message is a warning about the unintended consequences of one's creative work. The poet humorously resolves never to be as funny as he can be, for the sake of public safety.

My Opinion: I think this is a very funny and enjoyable poem. The idea of a poem being so humorous that it causes physical harm is brilliantly absurd. It's a creative way to explore the power of laughter.

text: Describe the effect of the funny poem on the poet's servant.
answer: The poem had a dramatic and comical effect on the servant. As he started reading, a grin appeared on his face, which spread from ear to ear. He let out a roar of laughter, and then a loud chuckle. His laughter became so intense that his waistcoat buttons burst off, and the strap of his pants broke. He laughed uncontrollably for ten days and nights, and by the end of it, he was reduced to a wreck, becoming extremely thin.

text: What resolution does the poet make at the end of the poem and why?
answer: At the end of the poem, the poet makes a resolution that from that day on, he will never write such a funny poem again. He makes this decision because he does not want to be responsible for the kind of extreme and harmful reaction his servant experienced. He decides to be sad and serious in his writing to avoid any further comical disasters.

text:
Read the following passage and answer the questions that follow.

A World Heritage Site is a site determined by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) to have significant cultural or natural importance to humanity. As such the sites are protected and maintained by the International World Heritage Programme which is administered by the UNESCO World Heritage Committee.

Because World Heritage Sites are places that are significant culturally and naturally, they vary in type and include forests, lakes, monuments, buildings and cities. World Heritage Sites can also be a combination of both cultural and natural areas. While a site’s uniqueness is one of the criteria for being chosen as a World Heritage Site, a site must also be ‘of outstanding universal value’ to be included on the World Heritage List.

A1. Simple Factual (2 marks)
Complete the following sentences:
(i) A World Heritage Site is determined by the organization called _______.
(ii) World Heritage Sites can be a combination of both _______ and _______ areas.

A2. Complex Factual (2 marks)
What are the two main criteria for a site to be included on the World Heritage List?

A3. Vocabulary (2 marks)
Find words from the passage that mean: (i) Importance (ii) Looked after

A4. Grammar (2 marks)
Do as directed:
(i) They vary in type. (Identify the tense)
(ii) A site's uniqueness is one of the criteria. (Rewrite using 'as well as')

A5. Personal Response (2 marks)
Why do you think it is important to protect and maintain World Heritage Sites?
answer:
A1.
(i) A World Heritage Site is determined by the organization called UNESCO.
(ii) World Heritage Sites can be a combination of both cultural and natural areas.

A2. The two main criteria are:
1. The site must be unique.
2. The site must be of 'outstanding universal value' to humanity.

A3. (i) significant / importance (ii) maintained

A4.
(i) Simple Present Tense.
(ii) A site's uniqueness as well as its value are criteria.

A5. I think it's very important to protect these sites because they are the shared treasures of all humanity, not just one country. They represent the best of our natural world and our shared cultural history. Protecting them means we are preserving this legacy for future generations to learn from and enjoy.
